section_purpose: This section provides formal proofs for Proposition 3.1, Proposition 3.2, and Theorem 3.1 from the main paper, which analyze the expected curvature of edges in random k-SAT graphs under different limits of the clause-to-variable ratio α.
key_points: Proposition 3.1 shows that as α = M/N → 0, the expected values of both κ(i,j) and Ric(i,j) approach 0 for edges in the Literal-Clause Graph.
Proposition 3.2 shows that as α → ∞, the expected value of the lower bound R̲(i,j) approaches (2/k) - 2, where k is the clause length.
Theorem 3.1 establishes an upper bound for the Balanced Forman Curvature (BFC) and proves that as α → ∞, the average BFC converges to (2/k) - 2.
The proofs leverage degree distributions, properties of bipartite graphs, and sandwiching techniques to derive limits.
The curvature bounds depend on node degrees and graph topology, with simplifications due to the bipartite nature of the LCG.

formulas: Expected literal degree limit as α → 0: lim E[d_i] = 1, derived from a Poisson-type distribution.
Upper bound for BFC: R̄(i,j) = 2/d_i + 2/d_j - 2 + (d_i + k - 2) / (max{k-1, M-1} * max{d_i, d_j}).
Definition of BFC for bipartite graphs: Ric(i,j) = 2/d_i + 2/d_j - 2 + (γ_max(i,j))^{-1} / max{d_i, d_j} * (|#_□^i| + |#_□^j|).
Limits for curvature expectations: as α → 0, E[κ(i,j)] = E[Ric(i,j)] = 0; as α → ∞, E[Ric(i,j)] → (2/k) - 2.

dependencies: Section 2.1 for background on random k-SAT problems and Literal-Clause Graph representation.
Appendix A.1.2 for definitions of Balanced Forman Curvature (BFC) and related terms.
Equations 6 and 3 from the paper for degree distributions of variables and clauses.
Proposition 3.1 and 3.2 from Section 3 for statements being proved.
reproducibility_notes: Need the exact forms of degree distributions (Equations 6 and 3) to compute expected degrees.
Require definitions of curvature bounds (lower bound R̲ and upper bound R̄) and BFC from Appendix A.1.2.
Understanding of limit operations, expected value linearity, and sandwiching techniques for convergence proofs.
Parameters: k (clause length), N (number of variables), M (number of clauses), α = M/N.
